I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  For  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  digital  finance  creates  new  enablers  for 
development impact and poverty alleviation at the macro, meso, and micro levels of the financial 
sector as well as the numerous crosscutting development themes across the ecosystem. ADB 
can assist in various ways. In the private sector, ADB can support digital finance by profiling 
champions and identifying funding opportunities that promote financial inclusion. In the public 
sector,  ADB  can  help  conceptualize  pilot  projects  for  government-to-person  projects,  and 
crucially assist governments as they craft fair and effective regulations that enable growth. Such 
advancement through financing and pilot projects, as well as improvement and implementation 
of regulation, will directly benefit all users of digital finance although specifically women; micro, 
small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs); and the base of the pyramid1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Digital finance, financial technology, and mobile money have been emerging areas of 
interest for ADB and other multilateral development banks, both for public sector and private 
sector  operations.2 These  areas  have  enormous  reach  and  interconnections  with  other 
technological  themes  such  as  “big  data”3 and  “the  internet  of  things”4 as  well  as  with 
infrastructure development. Digital finance will play a defining role in the future of the financial 
sector  globally.  Innovation  is  paving  the  way  for  new  applications  of  managing  financial 
transactions, encompassing trade, e-commerce, supply chain, loans, and investments.5 The 
private sector is at the heart of this change, given the valuable assets that are at stake - such as 
customer revenues, influence, and data.6 Most banks, to varying degrees, are embracing bank 
2.0 or bank 3.0 approaches that develop product offerings and core banking systems to meet 
evolving customer habits and/or preferences. Banks are also keen to ward off attacks from 
younger, more flexible, and targeted financial technology companies or “fintechs” that specialize 
in developing highly effective technology to create alternative finance modalities for customers7. 
Banks also must compete with or partner with mobile network operators (MNOs) that have an 
infrastructure and distribution advantage to build payment systems into their mobile proposition8. 
However, MNOs are often not licensed for activities in the finance sector, giving opportunity for 
strategic partnership for financial institutions. However, these new modalities affect the risk 
profile  of  financial  transactions.  Global,  regional,  and  local  regulators,  central  banks,  and 
politicians  are  watching  the  developments  in  global  financial  technology  with  an  eye  on 
balancing progress and innovation with prudent risk control. 
 
                                                
1  The largest but poorest socioeconomic group in a society. Usually defined as people living below $3 per day in 
Asia or a purchasing power parity equivalent for specific country in question. 
2  For more information, see the The MasterCard Foundation; International Finance Corporation (IFC). 2014. In the 
Fast Lane: Innovations on Digital Finance. Washington, DC; IFC. 2014. Alternative Delivery Channels and 
Technology Handbook. Washington, DC; and ADB. 2014. Making Mobile Financial Services Work for Central and 
West Asian Countries. Consultant’s report. Manila. (TA 7709-REG).  
3  Extremely large data sets that may be analyzed computationally to reveal patterns, trends, and associations, 
especially relating to human behavior and interactions. 
4  A proposed development of the internet in which everyday objects have network connectivity, allowing them to 
send and receive data. 
5  Oliver Wyman. 2015. Fintech 2.0 Paper: Rebooting Financial Services. New York. 
6  McKinsey & Company. 2011. The Road to Mobile Payments Services. New York. 
7  McKinsey & Company. 2015. McKinsey Global Banking Annual Review 2015: The Fight for the Customer. New 
York. Author Brett King coined Bank 2.0 and 3.0 referring to advancement of technology and disruption of the 
banking and financial services sector toward a unified digital experience and ecosystem. 
8  Ernst & Young. 2014. Mobile Money-the next wave of growth: Optimizing operator approaches in a fast-changing 
landscape. New York.

2   
3.  Key to ADB’s interest in digital finance is the pivotal role it can play in financial inclusion 
and  inclusive  finance.  In  East  Asia  and  the  Pacific  alone,  about  490  million  people  were 
unbanked in 2014.9 Many of these people live remotely and/or rurally. Owing to unequal access 
to infrastructure, made worse by low financial literacy and onerous know-your-customer and 
loan application requirements from financial institutions, this population are excluded from basic 
financial services. While the majority of the unbanked and underbanked population lacks regular 
access to the internet, mobile phones with MNO prepaid SIM (subscriber identity module) card 
are almost universal. Although this is not a substitute to a formal bank account, it is a key 
enabler  for  financial  inclusion  given  its  vast  distribution  network  (2.5  billion  of  the  world’s 
4.3 billion mobile phone users are in Asia and the Pacific,10 including 1.6 billion smartphone 
users).11 The crosscutting ecosystem benefits that build off of a network of mobile financial 
technology must also be considered for its development potential. Kenya’s M-Pesa is an oft-
quoted example of the effect of crowding in education, health care, and other applications 
across the M-Pesa ecosystem through application programming interface (API) technology.12 
ADB notes three specific beneficiaries that have outsized potential for financial inclusion as a 
result of digital finance - women, the base of the pyramid, and MSMEs. 
 
4.  Regulation, demand, awareness, infrastructure, technical understanding, education, and 
other  supply  considerations  all  affect  the  growth  of  the  digital  finance  market.  High  initial 
investments  but  low  near-term  returns,  high  customer  dropout  rates,  issues  related  to 
interoperability, and building critical agent networks, prevent growth. ADB can have a multi-
pronged approach to building capacity in digital finance. ADB’s non-sovereign operations can 
join other development investors by providing capital and technical assistance (TA) to private 
sector champions (both banks and nonbank technology companies ‘fintechs’) that are driving 
change and financial inclusion for key segments. ADB’s sovereign operations can assist by 
conceptualizing  pilot  projects  with  government  stakeholders  such  as  government-to-person 
payments, as a way to improve transparency, governance and reducing transaction costs. 
Crucially, ADB is well positioned to help tackle regulation—a key challenges (or enabler), with 
wide impact across the ecosystem. Regulation is pivotal for private sector operators to scale up 
operations and drive financial inclusion. Fair and well-crafted regulations are essential as they 
give comfort and trust to the market. They create a level playing field for companies to calculate 
risk—facilitating growth that will create financial inclusion. 
 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
5.  The TA will have two components: a “One ADB” public and private sector product 
focused on regulation, and a Private Sector Financial Institutions Division (PSFI)-only market 
scoping and investment building process that will run in parallel to the “One ADB” product. 
 
6.  Output 1: Regulatory analysis and road map. Combining resources from the PSFI, 
regional departments and the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department, a

Washington, DC. 
10 eMarketer and Starcom MediaVest Group. 2015. The Global Media Intelligence Report. New York.  
11 Bain  &  Company.  2015.  Asia’s  emerging  digital  consumers.  Insight  Infographics.  23  November. 
http://www.bain.com/publications/articles/asia-digital-consumers-infographic.aspx 
12 M-Pesa is a Kenya – based fintech company. C. Tellez-Merchan. 2015. Can Open APIs Accelerate the Digital 
Finance Ecosystem? Consultative Group to Assist the Poor (CGAP). 1 June. http://www.cgap.org/blog/can-open-
apis-accelerate-digital-finance-ecosystem (accessed November 2015).

3 
deep analysis of the financial technology ecosystem, value chain, and regulatory environment in 
targeted country contexts will be undertaken.13  
 
7.  Country  selection.  This  will  be  a  collaborative  process  with  member  countries  to 
identify needs assessment and project scope.  
 
8.  Output  2:  Private  Sector  Financial  Institutions  Division  investment  pipeline 
development. A separate PSFI-only market scoping and investment-building process will run in 
conjunction with output 1. Under the TA, PSFI will employ an individual consultant to build on 
the  value  chain  analysis  conducted  in  output  1.  Output  2  will  identify  and  analyze  risks 
associated with specific financial technology transactions in countries included in the report. The 
consultant will identify target segments and companies fit to ADB’s investment value proposition 
in debt and equity.  
 
9.  Justification. The digital finance space is moving incredibly fast, and governments need 
time to embrace and understand new technology—creating a regulatory lag. Bridging the gap 
between technology innovation and government decision making is vital. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The  impact  is  aligned  with  the  Sustainable  Development  Goals  (SDGs)  that  target 
productive activities, job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage 
the formalization and growth of MSMEs, including through access to financial services. The 
SDGs target a reduction in the number of unbanked people (SDG 1.4: By 2030, to ensure that 
all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have access to financial services). 
 
11.  The outcome will be for ADB investments in digital finance, financial technology, and 
mobile banking to be rolled out following the PSFI investment pipeline being identified and the 
regulatory road maps outlining preconditions for the development of an enabling environment 
for digital financial technology developed for each country.  
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources).14 
  
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The TA will be executed and implemented by ADB, with PSOD as the focal point. ADB, 
through PSOD, will be responsible for all technical implementation issues. The TA activities 
under output 1 will be implemented with the help of an international consulting firm with strong 
branding and will be a firm with proven experience in the area of digital finance both in the 
public and private sectors. The firm will also have experience developing knowledge papers, 
financial technology databases, and specific engagements on both public policy development 
and financial technology. Output 1 will require 7.5 person-months of international consultant 
services.  
                                                
13 Regional considerations will also be taken into account. This may require additional funding to identify, for 
example, remittance flows from country to country and regulation harmonization across governments. 
14 Certain outputs under this TA will be linked to those under the ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance for Establishing 
Sound Microinsurance Markets in Asia and the Pacific. Manila (TA 8528-REG). The cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. Ouput 2 will be linked to this TA.

4   
17.  Consultants for output 1 will be engaged via the consultants’ qualifications selection 
process in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended 
from time to time), as they require specific skills. For output 2, the consultant will be engaged via 
individual consultants selection process in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Outputs 1 will be 
implemented over 12 months from the start date (January–March 2016), for completion in April–
December 2016. Output2 1 will be implemented over 36 months from the start date (January–
March 2016), for completion in April–December 2018. 
 
18.  Both the consulting firm and the individual consultant will provide ADB with TA progress 
reports at the midterm point of their respective engagements, which outline the status of TA 
implementation in addition to a final TA report. Pursuant to Article 14(iii) of the ADB Charter,15 
the applicable developing member country's government's no objection to the implementation of 
the TA in the relevant country will be established before the implementation or financing of the 
TA in that country. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Promoting Financial Inclusion through Financial Technology, and hereby reports this action to 
the  Board.
                                                
15 ADB 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.
